items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns miscellaneous property that has been replaced with new and that has been determined to be in such poor condition that it is unusable. District staff estimates the resale value to be
less than $50.00 in the aggregate.
	 
California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale,
the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey. Interim Director. Purchasing Services, extension 6165
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the items are of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to recycle the items or dispose of them in the local public dump.
items.item_text: Recycle and Dispose of District Property
items.item_text_raw: 3. Recycle and Dispose of District Property

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns athletic equipment that was weather damaged while in storage (see attached Surplus Form). The Foothill College Divisional Dean of Kinesiology and Athletics has determined that the athletic equipment is unsatisfactory and unsafe for further use by the District. District staff estimates the resale value to be less than $50.00 in the aggregate. California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately. 
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey. Interim Director. Purchasing Services 
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Student Transfer Achievement Reform Act (Senate Bill 1440, now codified in California Education Code sections 66746-66749) guarantees admission to a California State University (CSU) campus for any community college student who completes an "associate degree for transfer", a newly established variation of the associate degrees traditionally offered at a California community college. The Associate in Arts for
Transfer (AA-T) or the Associate in Science for Transfer (AS-T) is intended for students who plan to complete a bachelor's degree in a similar major at a CSU campus. Students completing these degrees (AA-T or AS-T) are guaranteed admission to the CSU system, but not to a particular campus or major. In order to earn one of these degrees, students must complete a minimum of 60 required semester units of CSU-transferable coursework with a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students transferring to a CSU campus that does accept the AA-T or AS-T will be required to complete no more than 60 units after transfer to earn a bachelor's degree (unless the major is a designated "high-unit" major).
	 
De Anza College seeks Board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for a new degree developed based on Transfer Model Curriculum in order to fulfill the requirements set forth in SB 1440 Legislation. The following application is being made for state approval:
	 
Associate in Arts in Child Development and Education (AA-T)
	 
De Anza's Curriculum Committee has approved this Associate Degree for Transfer
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy, President, extension 8705
Additional contact names:
Karen Chow, Academic Senate President, extension 8358
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza President Brian Murphy recommends approval.
items.item_text: De Anza College Associate Degree for Transfer & State Approval
items.item_text_raw: 6. De Anza College Associate Degree for Transfer & State Approval

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Presented for review and first reading is new board policy (BP) 3500 Alcohol On Campus. This new policy is being recommended in order for the District to invoke a recent change in the law (Business & Professions Code section 25608) that provides for special events (section 25608 {a} (15)) to be included in the exceptions to the legal prohibition of alcoholic beverages on district property. The attached executive summary of the change in the law details the rationale for adoption of the new policy.
	 
District administrative procedures (AP) 3500 and 3501 have been revised to allow for the special events exemption in addition to the previously allowed exceptions for Foundation sponsored fundraising events (Section 25608{a}(10)) and for certain events at the Flint Center which are not sponsored by the College District and held while the Flint Center is under lease to a private, non-profit corporation (section 25608{a}(5)). The approved administrative procedures are included for clarification.
	 
Legal counsel vetted the new policy and revised procedures, and the Chancellor’s Advisory Council reviewed and approved both the changes to the administrative procedures and the new policy on January 25, 2013.
	 
The policy will be presented for approval at the March 11, 2013 Board of Trustees meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor of Business Services, extension 6201
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Presented for review and first reading are revisions to the policies related to disclosure of student records recommended to bring the district in line with federal and state regulations. The name of board policy (BP) 5050 has been changed from “Furnishing Information Concerning Students” to “Disclosure of Student Records,” and board policies 5045 Student Information and Educational Records and 5048 Furnishing Directory Information have been merged into the revised policy.  
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the policy changes on January 25, 2013. Also approved were procedural changes, attached for clarification, that changed the name of “AP 5045 The Family Educational Right and Privacy Act” to “AP 5050 Disclosure of Student Records” and altered sections of AP 3260 Electronic Information Security. 
	 
Board policy 5050 will be presented for adoption and policies 5045 and 5048 for revocation at the regular meeting of March 11, 2013.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, extension 6104
Additional contact names:
Joseph Moreau, Andrew LaManque

Yes

Background and Analysis:
	 
Provisions with SB 564 require local agencies to report all external investments on a quarterly basis. In accordance with the aforementioned requirement, attached is a listing of the District’s
investments as of December 31, 2012.
	 
The District’s cash of $261,908,894.80 is invested in the County’s Commingled Investments Pool. As of on December 31, 2012, the current yield on the commingled investments pool was 0.58%. As a comparison for the same time period, the yield on a two-year Treasury Note was 0.25%; the yield on a 6-month Treasury Bill was 0.11%; and the Local Agency Investment Fund (LAIF) was 0.32%.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, extension 6201
Additional contact names:
Hector Quinonez

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statement number 45 requires the district to treat Other Post Employment Benefits (OPEB) on an accrual basis, rather than on a pay-as-you-go basis. As a result, the district has contracted with the CalPERS California Employers’ Retiree Benefit Trust (CERBT), an irrevocable trust, to fund the district’s actuarial accrued liability.
	 
The district’s actuarial accrued liability as of June 30, 2012 was $117,564,565. As of June 30, 2012, the District has transferred $5,311,801 to the irrevocable trust. The fair market value of the funds held with the CERBT as of December 31, 2012 was $7,118,556.
	 
The Adopted Budget for 2012-13 included a contribution of $500,000 to fully fund the Annual Required Contribution (ARC) for this fiscal year. Staff will make this transfer of $500,000 to CERBT prior to June 30, 2013, as reflected in the 2012-13 Adopted Budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, extension 6201
Additional contact names:
Hector Quinonez
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On August 29, 2011, the Board of Trustees adopted procedures for pre-qualification of prospective bidders for public projects in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20651.5 and Public Contract Code section 20101.
	 
On December 7 and December 14, 2012, Purchasing Services advertised the Prequalification Questionnaire (PQ) #1348-420R in the San Jose Post Record and on Bidnet, and also notified nine (9) local Builders’ Exchanges.  Nineteen (19) contractors submitted the completed questionnaire to the District by the January 9, 2013 due date. The questionnaires were evaluated based upon the following key evaluation factors: license information, litigation history, construction experience, safety history, bonding capacity, insurance capacity, and financial capacity.  Public Contract Code Section 20101(a) mandates that the questionnaire responses of prospective bidders and their financial statements shall not be deemed public records and shall not be open to public inspection.
	 
Purchasing Services staff and the Foothill College Measure E Bond Program Director evaluated the responses and determined that fourteen (14) of the nineteen (19) contractors meet the minimum requirements of the prequalification questionnaire, including a point score of 80 or higher out of a total possible 100 points. 
	 
SUMMARY OF RESULTS
CONTRACTOR
PREQUALIFIED
Alpha Bay Builders, Inc.
No
Alten Construction, Inc.
Yes
S. J. Amoroso Construction Inc.
Yes
Arntz Builders Inc.
No
Beals Martin Associates Inc.
No
BMH Construction, Inc.
Yes
Calstate Construction Inc.
Yes
Cal-Pacific Construction Inc.
No
CLW Builders Inc.
Yes
D.L. Falk Construction Inc.
Yes
Gonsalves & Stronck
No
James R. Griffin Inc.
Yes
Lathrop Construction Associates Inc.
Yes
Jeff Luchetti Construction Inc.
Yes
John Plane Construction Inc.
Yes
Swenson & Associates
Yes
Taber Construction, Inc.
Yes
W.A. Thomas Inc.
Yes
Zolman Construction & Development Inc.
Yes
	 
The Board can choose to either:
          1.  Accept the list of fourteen (14) General Contractors who met all of the prequalification
requirements as the only prime contractors who are “prequalified” to bid on the District Office Building – Measure E project #420, OR
          2.  Cancel the prequalification procedure for this project.
	 
In order to be prequalified, Contractors were required to meet certain minimum requirements and achieve an overall score of 80% or more.  Contractors were required to (1) show that they have successfully completed renovation projects of similar size and scope of work; (2) provide information regarding litigation claims history; (3) provide verified documentation regarding its safety and OSHA history in the state of California; (4) provide information that confirms its ability to obtain insurance in the limits necessary for the project; (5) provide confirmation of its capacity to bond a project of the required size; and (6) provide three years of financial statements to verify debt ratios, liquidity ratios and positive profitability ratios.  
	 
Alpha Bay Builders Inc. does not meet the minimum Experience Modification Ratings (EMR) requirements within the PQ, which is a calculated average of 1.0 or less over the past three (3) years.  Its calculated three (3) year average exceeds 1.0.  The EMR is an insurance industry measurement of a company’s safety record that compares past actual experience to the expected or average experience. 
	 
Arntz Builders, Inc. earned a score of less than the required minimum 80 points to prequalify. The number of litigation claims reported and the number of safety citations reported resulted in overall low scores in these two categories.
	 
Beals Martin Associates, Inc. submitted an incomplete package, it submitted only one of three required reference projects and it submitted only two of three years financials statements required.  Furthermore, Beals Martin does not meet the minimum EMR requirements.  Beals Martin’s calculated three (3) year average exceeds 1.0.  
	 
Cal-Pacific Construction, Inc. did not submit the required project data sheets for its referenced projects. Cal-Pacific also did not submit the required signed declaration from its surety company that verifies its bonding capacity and it did not complete the requirements to verify its safety plan.  Even if Cal-Pacific would have submitted and completed the required documentation, its three-year averaged profitability ratio results in a net loss.  Therefore, Cal-Pacific is not able to meet the minimum requirement for the profitability ratio as stated in the PQ documents.
	 
Gonsalves & Stronck Construction Co., Inc.’s three-year averaged profitability ratio results in a net loss.  Therefore, it is not able to meet the minimum requirement for the profitability ratio as stated in the PQ documents.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Accept the list of fourteen (14) general contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only General Contractors who are “prequalified” to participate in the District Office Building – Measure E project #420.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On August 29, 2011, the Board of Trustees adopted procedures for prequalification of prospective bidders for public projects in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20651.5 and Public Contract Code section 20101.
	 
On October 24, 2012 and November 1, 2012, Purchasing Services advertised the Prequalification Questionnaire (PQ) #1624-115/173 in the San Jose Post Record as well posted it on “Bidnet” and also sent it to nine (9) local Builders’ Exchanges.  Eleven (11) contractors submitted the completed questionnaire to the District by the November 29, 2012 due date. The questionnaires were evaluated based upon the following key evaluation factors: license information, litigation history, construction experience, safety history, bonding capacity, insurance capacity, and financial capacity.  Public Contract Code Section 20101(a) mandates that the questionnaire responses of prospective bidders and their financial statements shall not be deemed public records and shall not be open to public inspection.
	 
Purchasing Services staff and the Foothill College Measure C Bond Program Director evaluated the responses and determined that eight (8) of the eleven (11) contractors meet the minimum requirements of the prequalification questionnaire, including a point score of 80 or higher out of a total possible 100 points. 
	 
SUMMARY OF RESULTS
CONTRACTOR
PREQUALIFIED
Alten Construction, Inc.
Yes
Arntz Builders, Inc. 
No
Beals Martin Associates, Inc. 
No
Calstate Construction, Inc. 
Yes
Dilbeck & Sons, Inc.
Yes
D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. 
Yes
James R. Griffin Inc. 
Yes
Jeff Luchetti Construction, Inc.
Yes
Swenson & Associates
Yes
Taber Construction, Inc. 
Yes
Transworld Construction, Inc. 
No
	 
The Board can choose to either:
          1. Accept the list of eight (8) General Contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements   
              as the only prime contractors who are “prequalified” to bid on Foothill College Measure C
              Projects #115 - Fine Arts Scene Shop or #173 - Print Shop and Plant Services, OR 
          2.  Cancel the prequalification procedure for this project.
	 
In order to be prequalified, Contractors were required to meet certain minimum requirements and achieve an overall score of 80% or more.  Contractors were required to (1) show that they have successfully completed renovation projects of similar size and scope of work; (2) provide information regarding litigation claims history; (3) provide verified documentation regarding its safety and OSHA history in the state of California; (4) provide information that confirms its ability to obtain insurance in the limits necessary for the project; (5) provide confirmation of its capacity to bond a project of the required size; and (6) provide three years of financial statements to verify debt ratios, liquidity ratios and positive profitability ratios.  
	 
Arntz Builders, Inc. earned a score of less than the required minimum 80 points to prequalify. The number of litigation claims reported and the number of safety citations reported resulted in overall low scores for these two categories.
	 
Beals Martin Associates, Inc. submitted an incomplete package; it submitted only one of three required reference projects and it submitted only two of three years financials statements required.  Furthermore, Beals Martin does not meet the minimum Experience Modification Ratings (EMR) requirements within the PQ, which is a calculated average of 1.0 or less over the past three (3) years.  Its calculated three (3) year average exceeds 1.0.  The EMR is an insurance industry measurement of a company’s safety record that compares past actual experience to the expected or average experience. 
	 
The other contractor that did not meet the prequalification requirements, Transworld Construction, Inc., also does not meet the minimum EMR requirements.  Transworld’s calculated three (3) year average exceeds 1.0.  Purchasing Services notified Transworld of the prequalification results in accordance with the PQ documents and Transworld responded with a request for a “Prequalification Appeal Hearing.”  After consulting with District legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret, Purchasing Services conducted an appeal hearing for Transworld on January 25, 2013.  Annette Perez, Senior Buyer, and Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services, represented the District. Mr. Eric Lui represented Transworld. As a result of the hearing, Purchasing Services confirmed Transworld’s OSHA safety citations and its EMR average, and therefore the scoring for Transworld remained unchanged.   Hence, Purchasing Services notified Transworld that it would recommend that the Board of Trustees not prequalify Transworld for Measure C Projects #115 - Fine Arts Scene Shop or #173 - Print Shop and Plant Services.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Accept the list of eight (8) general contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only General Contractors who are âprequalifiedâ to participate in the Measure C Foothill Projects #115 - Fine Arts Scene Shop or #173 - Print Shop and Plant Services.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As the major projects of Measure C move toward completion, various smaller Foothill College, De Anza College, and District projects will require design services.   The design of small projects can often be done more effectively and inexpensively by small firms or those that specialize in smaller projects.
	 
In August, 2012 the District issued Request for Qualifications (RFQ) #1621 for Design Services for Small Projects. The intent of the RFQ was to establish a pool of architecture and landscape architecture firms qualified to provide services for projects to be undertaken by the District over the next three years.  This group was not intended to replace firms already selected, but to augment that group with firms focused on small projects. 
	 
The RFQ was advertised on Bidnet and local firms thought to be qualified were contacted directly and encouraged to apply.  On September 18, 2012, the District received responses to the RFQ from thirty-four firms interested in the design of small projects. 
	 
A selection committee deliberated regarding the completeness and quality of responses, experience related to District projects, qualifications and experience of proposed team members and fee structure. Because the amount of work available for the small projects is not extensive, twelve firms were identified as being best qualified:  ANLA Associates, Inc.; Artik Art & Architecture; Bellinger Foster Steinmetz; John Miller Architects; K2A Architects + Interiors; Keller and Daseking Architects; MdKim Design Group; Meyer + Silberberg Land Architects; Prodis Associates Architects; Sissela Malmstrom Architect; Studio Perez; and Verde Design Group.  
	 
No commitment was made in the RFQ to employ every selected firm; final selections to provide services for individual projects will be based upon project needs, experience and qualification related to the project, availability relative to project schedules, references, and comparative cost proposals.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Exec. Dir. of Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich x6295, Tom Armstrong x8289, Annette Perez x6163, Gina Bailey x6165
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Executive Director of Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management Charles Allen recommends that the Board approve the list of twelve firms to be included in a Small Projects Design Pool.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis: 
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill and De-Anza College.  
	 
De-Anza Budget Transfer #36 includes the following actions:
Transfer project savings in the amount of $1,157,256.48 from Project 227 Window Replacement Campus-Wide and $101,990 from Project 252 Elevator Upgrades – Campus Wide into Project 216 Library to fund additional scope.  Project 227 is financially complete.
Transfer project savings in the amount of $55,225.70 from Project 226 Campus Wide Replacement/Repair of Interior and Exterior Finishes into Project 214 Corporation Yard to fund the project.  Project 226 is financially complete. 
Transfer $140,000 from Project 261 Media & Learning Center into Project 248 Campus Drive to fund previous borrowing.  (Reference DA Budget Transfer #26)
Transfer $24,826.14 (Series A), $12,004.64 (Series B) and $143,499.56 (Series C) of interest earned in Quarter 4 Fiscal Year 2011/2012 to Project 201 A8 to pay back previous borrowing and fund the project in full to the original budget of $2,790,635.  (Reference DA Budget Transfer #26)
Foothill Budget Transfer #38  includes the following actions:
Transfer a portion of scope & budget ($130,000) from Project 100, Scheduled Maintenance to Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms.  This transfer will cover the costs of structural repairs for the glu-lam beam ends at Buildings 5400, 5600 and 5800.  
Transfer a portion of scope & budget ($100,000) from Project 111, Swing Space to Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms. This transfer will cover a portion of the cost associated with the Disability Resource Center temporary relocation.
Transfer a portion of budget ($520,000) from Project 112, Modernization of Administration Building and General Classrooms to Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms.  Construction of Project 112 is complete.
Transfer savings ($86,198.62) from Project 110, LA General Classrooms to Project 105.  Project 110 is financially complete.
Transfer savings (277,002.66) from Project 142, Soccer and Softball Complex to Project 118, Storage Building at Swim Pool Area. Project 142 is financially complete.
Transfer a portion of budget (2,163,801.38) from Project 199, Foothill Program Contingency to Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General Classrooms to allow completion of project 105 as planned.  This transfer from contingency is essentially the use of interest earnings allocated to Project 199 in previous budget transfers; the original contingency amount remains intact.
Transfer $36,830.79 (Series B) and $143,449.56 (Series C) of interest earned in Quarter 4 Fiscal Year 2011/2012 to Project 199, Foothill Program Contingency.
Transfer a portion of budget (500,000) from Project 199, Foothill Program Contingency to form a new Foothill Project 175, Repair and Upgrade Miscellaneous Projects.  This new project is initiated to complete small projects to upgrade and repair campus facilities and improve accessibility.  The project scope is planned to include:  interior and exterior building finishes and systems, site improvements including site utilities, security and  parking payment infrastructure and equipment, stair and ramp handrail upgrades and miscellaneous signage installations.  Project 175 description is as follows:  Small projects to upgrade and repair campus facilities and to improve accessibility on the Foothill Campus.
Submitted by:
Charles Allen
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Bernata Slater, Tom Armstrong and Donna Jones-Dulin
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Charles Allen, Executive Director of Facilities, Operations and Construction Management recommends that the Board approve the Bond Project List Revision with Foothill Budget Transfer #38 and De-Anza Budget Transfer #36

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
At its August 27, 2012 meeting, the Board of Trustees accepted a list of five (5) contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only prime contractors who were “prequalified” to bid on the Foothill College Measure C Project #105 – Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology, and General Classrooms.
	 
The project is a complete renovation of five classroom buildings (Buildings 5100, 5400, 5600, 5700, and 5800). The scope of work includes hazardous material abatement; interior floor plan changes and new interior finishes; new exterior finishes; structural repairs and new roofing for building 5800; and new HVAC equipment and controls, electrical, lighting, plumbing, fire alarm, and telecommunications systems throughout.  The project also includes landscaping of areas surrounding the buildings, improvements to two courtyards, and site work required for installation of a modular office building for temporary relocation of some building occupants. The improvements to the two courtyards were identified as deductive alternates in the Bid Proposal, and the contract award will not include  construction of that scope.
	 
HMC Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid 1623-105 was legally advertised on December 14 and December 21, 2012.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com. Bids were publicly opened and read on February 7, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
CONTRACTOR
BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
DEDUCTIVE ALTERNATE #1 – Courtyard O
DEDUCTIVE ALTERNATE #2 – Courtyard N
TOTAL AMOUNT
S. J. Amoroso Construction Co., Inc.
$10,847,000
($110,000)
($187,000)
$10,550,000
Swenson & Associates
$10,990,000
($172,000)
($141,000)
$10,677,000
C. W. Driver, Inc.
$11,600,000
($  79,000)
($145,000)
$11,376,000
	 
The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is S. J. Amoroso Construction Co., Inc. (Amoroso). Furthermore, Amoroso and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
The architect’s estimate for the project (including acceptance of deductive bid alternates) was $8,120,000.  The corresponding total bid amount of $10,550,000 exceeds the amount budgeted for the project.  
The scope of this project is very similar to past Foothill College building renovations but has produced a higher price, indicating that bid prices have begun to rise from their lows of the past several years.  It is also likely that the estimate did not anticipate all costs related to the way the project is phased to allow laboratory classes to continue during construction.  
	 
The three bids received were quite similar, indicating that they represent the true market value of the work and that it is unlikely that rebidding the project will produce a better result.  Because of that consideration and because the project renovates critical teaching spaces, a budget transfer proposed on this Board agenda will augment the budget to allow completion of the project as planned.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1623-105 for the base bid proposal amount less the two deductive alternates in the aggregate amount of $10,550,000 to S. J. Amoroso Construction Co., Inc.
